solution_line_template: Tara has to make a ${laptop_cost} x {down_payment_percentage} = $<<{laptop_cost}*{down_payment_percentage}={initial_down_payment}>>{initial_down_payment} down payment.

Since Tara wants to pay ${additional_down_payment} more for the down payment, her total down payment will be ${initial_down_payment} + ${additional_down_payment} = $<<{initial_down_payment}+{additional_down_payment}={total_down_payment}>>{total_down_payment}.
So her remaining balance payable over a year is ${laptop_cost} - ${total_down_payment} = $<<{laptop_cost}-{total_down_payment}={remaining_balance_initial}>>{remaining_balance_initial}.

Tara has to make a monthly payment of ${remaining_balance_initial}/year / {months_per_year} months/year = $<<{remaining_balance_initial}/{months_per_year}={monthly_payment_calculated}>>{monthly_payment_calculated}/month.

The total cost of her payments for {number_of_months_paid} months is ${monthly_payment_calculated}/month x {number_of_months_paid} months = $<<{monthly_payment_calculated}*{number_of_months_paid}={total_payments_for_4_months}>>{total_payments_for_4_months}.

Therefore, Tara's balance after {number_of_months_paid} months is ${remaining_balance_initial} - ${total_payments_for_4_months} = $<<{remaining_balance_initial}-{total_payments_for_4_months}={final_balance}>>{final_balance}.
